content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata> <idinfo> <citation> <citeinfo> <origin>CEHTP Science Team</origin> <pubdate>20140624</pubdate> <title>Unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning hospitalization  and emergency department counts and rates by county, year, and fire-relatedness among California residents,2000-2012 </title> <onlink>http://www.ehib.org/page.jsp?page_key=458</onlink> </citeinfo> </citation> <descript> <abstract>This dataset contains case counts, rates, and confidence intervals of unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning (CO) inpatient hospitalizations and emergency department (ED) visits among California residents. Inpatient hospitalization data are aggregated into 5-year groupings for years 2000-2012.  ED visit data are annual for years 2005-2012.  Types of CO poisonings are broken out by fire-related, non-fire-related, and unknown cause.  The data are stratified by county, year, and fire-relatedness. </abstract> <purpose>To provide data that is consistent with the National Environmental Public Health Tracking Network guidance for creating the CO poisoning inpatient hospitalization and emegency department visit Nationally Consistent Data and Measures (NCDMs). </purpose> <supplinf>Data have been de-identified to protect patient confidentiality.  CO poisoning hospitalizations are selected based on admitting diagnosis coding.    The California EPHT Program receives calendar year hospitalization and emergency department data annually from the Office of Statewide Health Planning and Development (OSHPD).  Further information on OSHPD is located at:  www.oshpd.ca.gov.  All state licensed hospitals in California are required by California Health and Safety Code to report to OSHPD data elements for each inpatient discharged from the hospital and each emergency department visit.  The facilities submit their data via the Medical Information Reporting for California (MIRCal), an on-line data transmission method.  Additional fields are computed by OSHPD.   </supplinf> </descript> <timeperd> <timeinfo> <rngdates> <begdate>20000101</begdate> <begtime/> <enddate>20121231</enddate> <endtime/> </rngdates> County, 06093, Siskiyou County, 06095, Solano County,</placekey> <placekey>06097, Sonoma County, 06099, Stanislaus County, 06101, Sutter County,</placekey> <placekey>06103, Tehama County, 06105, <accconst>Restricted (secure) data will only be released to external users after the California EPHT Program and representatives from OSHPD have reviewed the request. The request must include an Application for Release of Restricted Data along with the Data Use Agreement and, if deemed necessary, a research protocol and proof of approval by, or exemption from, an Institutional Review Board (IRB) formed and maintained in accordance with the U.S. Dept. of Health and Human Services Code of Federal Regulations for Protection of Human Subjects (45 CFR 46, revised March 8, 1983). The California Committee for the Protection of Human Subjects serves as the institutional review board (IRB) for the California Health and Human Services Agency. Information is available at: http://www.oshpd.ca.gov/boards/cphs/ . </accconst> <useconst>This information is provided by the California Environmental Health Tracking Program (CEHTP) in the California Department of Public Health and the Office of Statewide Health Planning and Development (OSHPD) in the California Health and Human Services Agency.  Efforts have been made to assure the accuracy of the data.  However, no responsibility is assumed by CEHTP or OSHPD, related to materials or how it is represented by those who access this information.  All users must read and fully comprehend metadata prior to data use.   Data may only be used in the manner specified in the data request proposal.  Data will not be released, furnished, disclosed, published or otherwise disseminated to any person (except for employees under supervision of data requestor, who has agreed in writing to comply with these conditions), unless the data has been aggregated and all cell sizes less than 5 are suppressed. </useconst> <ptcontac> <cntinfo> <cntperp> <cntper>CEHTP Science Team</cntper> <cntorg>CA Department of Public Health, CA Environmental Health Tracking Program</cntorg> </cntperp> <cntpos/> <cntaddr> <addrtype>Mailing</addrtype> <address>850 Marina Bay Parkway, Bldg P, 3rd Floor</address> <city>Richmond</city> <state>CA</state> <postal>94804</postal> <country>United States Of America</country> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>5106203620</cntvoice> <cnttdd/> <cntfax>5106203720</cntfax> <cntemail>data@cehtp.org</cntemail> <hours/> <cntinst/> </cntinfo> </ptcontac> <secinfo> <secsys>None</secsys> <secclass>Restricted</secclass> <sechandl>Restricted data released to an external partner may not be disseminated or distributed in a manner inconsistent with the California Department of Public Health and the Office of Statewide Health Planning and Development (OSHPD)</sechandl> </secinfo> <native>SAS 9.1</native> </idinfo> <dataqual> <logic>NA</logic> <complete>These data include inpatient hospitalizations and emergency department visits of individuals who are discharged from all licensed hospitals in California.  These data are based on all diagnosis codes (ICD9-CM) available in the data (up to 24 diagnosis codes reported in California).  </complete> <lineage> <procstep> <procdesc>Since 1986, the Office of Statewide Health Planning and Development (OSHPD) has been responsible for routinely collecting data on hospital discharges from every licensed acute care hospital in California, excluding federal hospitals.  Each year, OSHPD compiles the data from all hospitals to create the Patient Discharge Database (PDD) and Emergency Department database.  Each year, CEHTP obtains the PDD and ED dataset from OSHPD and creates datasets to be used for public health surveillance, while maintaining confidentiality.  This dataset on the CEHTP portal includes hospitalizations  unintentional carbon monoxide poisonings for the years 2001 to 2012.  Each event is identified by looking at all diagnosis codes (up to 24) based on the International Classification of Disease, Ninth Revision, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM).   Each hospitalization event is identified based on date of discharge from the hospital. Counts, rates, and confidence intervals were calculated by county, age-group, gender, and race/ethnicity. We use population data from the California Department of Finance (DOF) For years 2000-2010: DOF uses the 2000 and 2010 population data collected by the U.S. Census Bureau and takes into account births, deaths, and migration for California to estimate the intercensal California population by county, race/ethnicity, age, and gender for 2000-2010 (State of California, Department of Finance, Race/Hispanics Population with Age and Gender Detail, 2000\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd2010. Sacramento, California, September 2012.).Years 2011-2012: DOF used the 2010 population data collected by the U.S. Census Bureau and takes into account survival rates, migration patterns, and fertility rates for California to project the California population by county, race/ethnicity, age, and gender for 2010-2060 (State of California, Department of Finance, Report P-3: State and County Population Projections by Race/Ethnicity, Detailed Age, and Gender, 2010-2060. Sacramento, California, January 2013.)To calculate rates, we use population data from the California Department of Finance (DOF).  DOF uses year 2000 population data collected by the U.S. Census Bureau and takes into account survival rates, migration patterns, and fertility rates for California to project the California population by county, race/ethnicity, age, and gender for 2000-2050 (State of California, Department of Finance, Population Projections for California and Its Counties 2000-2050, Sacramento, California, July 2007). Confidence intervals for rates of hospitalizations are calculated using a method developed by Tiwari, Clegg, and Zou (Methods in Medical Research, 2006; 15:547-569).</procdesc> <procdate>20140624</procdate> </procstep> </lineage> </dataqual> <eainfo> <overview> <eaover>This data contains the following fields: Cnty_FIPS Start_Date End_Date Measure_ID Measure_VA.  For hospitalizations, case counts are aggregated into 4-year intervals according to admission year, county, and type of CO-poisoning. For ED visits, case counts are annual by year, county, and type of CO-poisoning. The types of intentional CO-poisonings included are: fire-related, non-fire related, and unknown cause.</eaover> <eadetcit>None</eadetcit> </overview> </eainfo> <distinfo> <distrib> <cntinfo> <cntperp> <cntper>CEHTP Science Team</cntper> <cntorg>CA Department of Public Health, CA Environmental Health Tracking Program</cntorg> </cntperp> <cntpos/> <cntaddr> <addrtype>Mailing</addrtype> <address>850 Marina Bay Parkway, Bldg P, 3rd Floor</address> <city>Richmond</city> <state>CA</state> <postal>94804</postal> <country>United States Of America</country> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>5106203620</cntvoice> <cnttdd/> <cntfax>5106203720</cntfax> <cntemail>data@cehtp.org</cntemail> <hours/> <cntinst/> </cntinfo> </distrib> <resdesc/> <distliab>Persons or entities given access to restricted data are liable for compliance with conditions set forth in the data use agreement. Disciplinary action will be incurred for non-compliance or violation of data use agreements.</distliab> <custom>For access to restricted or secure data please see Access contraints section for release of restricted data.</custom> </distinfo> <metainfo> <metd>20100924</metd> <metc> <cntinfo> <cntperp> <cntper>CEHTP Science Team</cntper> <cntorg>CA Department of Public Health, CA Environmental Health Tracking Program</cntorg> </cntperp> <cntpos/> <cntaddr> <addrtype>Mailing</addrtype> <address>850 Marina Bay Parkway, Bldg P, 3rd Floor</address> <city>Richmond</city> <state>CA</state> <postal>94804</postal> <country>United States Of America</country> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>5106203620</cntvoice> <cnttdd/> <cntfax>5106203720</cntfax> <cntemail>data@cehtp.org</cntemail> <hours/> <cntinst/> </cntinfo> </metc> <metstdn>EPHTN Tracking Network Profile Version 1.2</metstdn> <metac>None</metac> <metuc>None</metuc> </metainfo> </metadata>
